awd_titl_txt: AMPS:   Advanced Mathematical Algorithms for Model Reduction and Stochastic Modeling for the Emerging Power Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop tools to analyze and help design robust and resilient modern power grid systems. The emergent power grid is very different from the traditional grid, which is based on technology dating back to the early 20'th century. With new technologies and regulatory policies, new challenges are arising in the design of stable power systems that can reliably deliver electric power. To tackle these challenges, mathematical and computational tools are needed to analyze these power grids with the new features. The goal of this project is to develop these mathematical and computational tools. 
 
Specifically, this project will examine model reduction, uncertainty/stochasticity, and stability, which are some of the new features that must be incorporated in the models of the modern grid. Stability will be the connecting theme in these topics since stability is required to ensure a resilient grid with reduced risks. The PI will examine (1) how synchrony in the oscillations of the grid can be used to determine coherent sets of generators and loads for accurate model reduction; (2) what are the relevant structures that must be reserved to produce accurate reduced models; (3) how to develop multilevel solvers for decentralized systems; (4) how stochasticity affects the synchrony, coherency, model reduction, and stability of the grid; and (5) how observed data can be assimilated into the stochastic models. The stochasticity will be incorporated using stochastic differential-algebraic equations. This stochasticity will be introduced using the Orstein-Uhlenbeck process that best describes the stochasticity in the components of the system.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to develop mathematical tools to analyze and help design robust and resilient modern power systems. Emergent power systems are vastly different from traditional ones, which are based on technology from over a century ago. With the incorporation of new technologies and regulatory policies, the grid and its operation are fundamentally changing. On top of this, climate change has led to devastating power outages, a concern that must be considered in designing resilient power systems. Since a power system is described by mathematical equations, in this project, we examined these equations to extract intrinsic mathematical structures that can provide insight into developing these tools. The key feature extracted is the spatial multi-scale structure, which is veiled in the transmission network. Exploiting this multi-scale structure, we were able to develop a systematic approach for constructing accurate and stable reduced models of dynamical power systems, fast and robust solvers for determining the power flow in the network, and accurate measures for determining the generators or loads that are most relevant in the flow of electricity through the network. Regarding reduced models, this permits the efficient study of large-scale power systems involving many parameters, i.e., an accurate reduced model allows one to efficiently explore the effects of different parameters on the system. Regarding fast and robust solvers, this permits not only quick computation of the states of the power system but also the robustness allows the handling of uncertainty in the initial states. Regarding accurate measures for generators/loads, these measures can be used in contingency analysis to determine which parts of the grid must be hardened to prevent outages and to guide the planning of re-routing of delivery of power in outages.

Mentoring and training of graduate and undergraduate students in the mathematical foundation of the power grid were components of this project, as well as graduate course development. As a result, an under-represented graduate student completed his PhD in this project. Furthermore, organization of workshops for graduate student internships at the Department of Energy Laboratories was performed. These internships provided training and experience for students to work on power grid applications.

The power grid is a vital component of the national infrastructure. With the modernization of the power grid, and along with it, the devastating effects of climate change, designing robust and resilient systems will have societal benefits. The mathematical results and techniques developed in this project provide several tools that can help in the design of such systems.


Last Modified: 11/24/2023
Modified by: Barry Lee
